contrastive_comparison.description: Comparing two subjects where both share a quality, but one is notable/surprising

patterns.japanese_structure: AはBだが、CもBだ / AはBけど、CはBだ
patterns.english_pattern: X is one thing, but Y is [quality]

examples.jp: 真理亜は変だが、如月さんも結構変だ
examples.literal: Maria's weird, but Kisaragi-san is pretty weird in her own right
examples.natural: Maria's one thing, but Kisaragi-san is pretty weird in her own right

usage_rules: both subjects share the same quality
First subject sets baseline expectation
Second subject exceeds/matches in surprising way

patterns.japanese_structure: だけでなく / ばかりでなく
patterns.english_pattern: not just X, but Y / not only X but (also) Y

examples.jp: 彼女は美しいだけでなく、頭もいい
examples.literal: She is not only beautiful, but also smart
examples.natural: She's not just beautiful—she's brilliant too

usage_rules: Use em dash (—) for emphasis in casual writing
'not just' is more conversational than 'not only'
Can drop 'also' for punchier delivery

patterns.japanese_structure: はおろか / どころか
patterns.english_pattern: let alone X / much less X / never mind X

examples.jp: 歩くどころか、立つこともできない
examples.literal: Forget about walking, I can't even stand
examples.natural: I can't even stand, let alone walk

usage_rules: 'let alone' is most natural in modern English
Order: lesser impossibility comes first
Emphasizes extreme inability

dismissive_acknowledgment.description: Acknowledging something while dismissing its importance

patterns.japanese_structure: Aはともかく / Aは置いといて
patterns.english_pattern: X aside, ... / Putting X aside, ...

examples.jp: 君はともかく、彼女は絶対怒る
examples.literal: Putting you aside, she would definitely get mad
examples.natural: You're one thing, but she'd definitely get mad

usage_rules: dismissing first subject to focus on second
Can combine with 'one thing' pattern

patterns.english_pattern: Provisional action or starting point

examples.natural: You came all the way here? / You didn't have to come

usage_rules: Appreciation: 'all the way', 'You didn't have to'

patterns.english_pattern: Concluding despite expectations

examples.jp: 結局、行かなかった
examples.literal: In the end, I didn't go
examples.natural: I ended up not going / I never did go

patterns.english_pattern: Hedging or minimal fulfillment

usage_rules: Precaution: 'just in case', 'to be safe'
Qualification: 'technically', 'sort of', 'I guess'

patterns.english_pattern: Acknowledging comprehension

examples.jp: なるほど、そういうことか
examples.literal: I see, so that's how it is

usage_rules: Understanding: 'I see', 'Makes sense', 'I get it'
Realization: 'Ah', 'Oh', 'So that's why'
Casual: 'Gotcha', 'Right', 'Fair enough'

patterns.english_pattern: Multi-purpose softener/intensifier

Softening: 'a little', or often just omit

usage_rules: Clarification: 'For the record', 'Just so you know'
Additional: 'By the way', 'Oh, and'

logical_flow.description: Japanese logical connectors that need natural English equivalents

patterns.japanese_structure: だって / なぜなら at start of explanation
patterns.english_pattern: After all, ... / I mean, ... / It's just that ...

examples.literal: Because Maria is my childhood friend
examples.natural: After all, she's my childhood friend / I mean, Maria's my childhood friend

usage_rules: Use 'After all' for reasoning/justification
Use 'I mean' for clarification in casual speech
Don't start with bare 'Because' in English

emphasis_restructuring.description: Japanese emphasis particles that need English restructuring

double_negatives.description: Japanese double negatives that sound awkward in literal English

japanese_indicators: ないわけにはいかない
patterns.english_pattern: have to [verb] / can't not [verb] / must [verb]

examples.natural: I have to do it / I can't just not do it

usage_rules: Prefer single positive statement when possible
Keep double negative only for emphatic effect
Match formality level

rhetorical_questions.description: Japanese rhetorical questions requiring English restructuring

patterns.english_pattern: right? / don't you think? / isn't it?

examples.jp: 変じゃない？
examples.literal: Isn't it weird?
examples.natural: That's weird, right? / Kinda weird, don't you think?

usage_rules: Place 'right?' at end for casual speech
Use 'don't you think?' for softer tone
Can restructure as statement + tag question

conditional_restructuring.description: Japanese conditional forms requiring natural English equivalents

patterns.english_pattern: if only X / as long as X / all you need is X

examples.jp: 君さえいれば、他に何もいらない
examples.literal: If only you are here, I don't need anything else
examples.natural: As long as I have you, I don't need anything else

usage_rules: 'if only' often implies wistful impossibility
'as long as' is more confident/assertive
'all you need' works for positive emphasis

patterns.english_pattern: if X had [past], Y would have [past participle]

examples.literal: If I came earlier, I could have met her
examples.natural: If I'd come earlier, I would've met her / Had I come earlier, I'd have met her

usage_rules: Use contracted forms for casual speech (I'd, would've)
Formal: can invert to 'Had I come...'
Past counterfactual requires 'would have' not 'would'

patterns.english_pattern: provided (that) / as long as / so long as

examples.literal: As long as you keep your promise, I'll help you
examples.natural: I'll help you, provided you keep your promise

usage_rules: 'provided' is more formal/contractual
'as long as' is casual and common
Can place condition before or after main clause

perfect_aspect_nuances.description: Subtleties in perfect tense usage for completed actions with present relevance

patterns.english_pattern: have [past participle] / have been to

examples.jp: 日本に行ったことがある

Simple past only if specific time mentioned
'have been to' specifically for places visited

examples.natural: I'd already left by the time he arrived / I had left before he came

usage_rules: Use past perfect for earlier of two past events
'by the time' emphasizes temporal relationship

Can add 'than' for explicit comparison
Often contracted to 'I'd rather'

Keep 'the fact that' only for emphasis

patterns.english_pattern: Restructure with who/which/that or split sentences

Split long relative clauses into separate sentences
Avoid stacking multiple relative clauses

active_passive_optimization.description: Choosing between active and passive voice for clarity

Keep passive only when focus is on receiver

usage_rules: Sentence-initial: 'But', 'Still', 'Then again', 'That said'

Farewell: 'See you', 'Later', 'Catch you later'

patterns.english_pattern: However/But/Still/And yet

examples.jp: しかし、彼女には高い評価をしてもらえているらしい。

usage_rules: Narration: 'Still', 'And yet', 'Of course' — avoid 'Howev...

patterns.english_pattern: In other words/Basically/So basically/What I mean is

examples.jp: つまり、彼女は俺のことが嫌いなわけじゃない。
examples.literal: In other words, it's not that she hates me.
examples.natural: So it's not that she hates me or anything.

usage_rules: Casual: 'Basically', 'So', 'Long story short'
Explanatory: 'In other words', 'What I'm saying is'
Impatient: 'Point is', 'Bottom line'

patterns.english_pattern: Anyway/In any case/Point is/Look

examples.literal: Anyway, let's concentrate on what's in front of us now.

usage_rules: Topic redirect: 'Anyway', 'Moving on', 'Setting that aside'
Emphasis: 'Seriously', 'Just', 'The point is'
Impatient: 'Look', 'Just', 'Enough'

Casual: 'Plus', 'And' — Formal: 'Furthermore', 'Moreover'

patterns.english_pattern: Because/But/I mean/Well

examples.jp: 「だって、仕方ないじゃん」
examples.literal: 'Because, it can't be helped.'
examples.natural: 'Well, what was I supposed to do?'

usage_rules: Childish/defensive: 'But', 'I mean', 'Well' + reason
Often restructure: move reason first, drop だって entirely
Whiny: 'But [reason]!' — Casual: 'I mean, [reason]'

advanced_patterns.description: Advanced grammar patterns for literary and sophisticated writing

subjunctive_mood.description: Subjunctive mood for hypothetical, wishes, and demands

patterns.japanese_structure: ～たらいいのに / ～ればいいのに

examples.jp: 彼女がここにいたらいいのに
examples.literal: It would be good if she was here
examples.natural: I wish she were here / If only she were here

usage_rules: Use 'were' for all persons in formal subjunctive
'I wish' for present contrary-to-fact
'I wish' + had + past participle for past regret

inversion_structures.description: Subject-verb inversion for emphasis and formality

patterns.english_pattern: even though / despite / in spite of

examples.jp: 雨が降っているにもかかわらず、彼は出かけた
examples.literal: Despite the rain falling, he went out
examples.natural: Even though it was raining, he went out / He went out despite the rain

usage_rules: 'even though' + clause (subject + verb)
'despite/in spite of' + noun/gerund only
'although' is more formal than 'even though'

patterns.japanese_structure: いくら～ても / どんなに～ても

examples.natural: However hard I try, I just can't do it / Much as I try, it's impossible

usage_rules: 'much as' is literary/formal
'no matter how' is more common
'however' + adjective/adverb (no 'very')

participial_phrases.description: Using participles for concise, sophisticated prose

patterns.english_pattern: [verb+ing], [main clause] / [main clause], [verb+ing]

examples.jp: 音楽を聴きながら、勉強した
examples.literal: While listening to music, I studied
examples.natural: Listening to music, I studied / I studied, listening to music

usage_rules: Participle and main verb must share same subject
More concise than 'while' clauses
Can place at start or end for emphasis

patterns.english_pattern: [past participle], [main clause]

examples.literal: Being surprised, he lost words
examples.natural: Shocked, he was speechless / Taken aback, he couldn't speak

usage_rules: Omit 'being' when implied
Creates more vivid, immediate prose
Subject of participle = subject of main clause

nominalization_reduction.description: Avoiding excessive nominalization for clearer prose

patterns.english_pattern: can [verb] (not 'can do the [verb+ing] of')

examples.jp: 彼は速く走ることができる
examples.literal: He can do the running quickly
examples.natural: He can run fast

usage_rules: Prefer verbs over abstract nouns
Avoid 'make/do/have' + nominalization
Exception: established phrases like 'make a decision'

patterns.english_pattern: Reduce to single verb when possible

examples.jp: 彼女の歌う行為は美しい
examples.literal: The act of her singing is beautiful
examples.natural: She sings beautifully / Her singing is beautiful

usage_rules: Reduce 'the act of [gerund]' to gerund alone
Convert noun phrases to verbs for clarity
Keep nominalization only for technical/legal writing

redundancy_reduction.description: Avoiding repetitive terms in close proximity by using pronouns or demonstratives for natural flow

patterns.english_pattern: Use 'that', 'it', 'this', 'one' for second mention

examples.natural:
As Kazehaya had just mentioned, it looked like they had decided to invite the entire class to participate in this test of courage.

They must have thought just doing that would be boring, so they decided to collect a participation fee and even prepare prizes.

usage_rules: When noun phrase appears in sentence N, use pronoun/demon...
Applies when referent is clear from immediate context
Use 'that' for abstract concepts just mentioned

patterns.english_pattern: Use 'doing that', 'doing so', 'that' for second mention

examples.literal:

But I decided going to the party was necessary.
examples.natural:
I was nervous about going to the party.

But I decided it was necessary.
examples.fix: going to the party → it (action already stated)

usage_rules: Replace repeated gerund phrases with pronouns
Use 'doing that' when emphasizing the action aspect
Use 'it' when treating action as a thing/state

japanese_indicators: Character name at start of consecutive sentences
patterns.english_pattern: Use pronoun after first mention in paragraph

examples.natural:

usage_rules: Use pronouns for same subject in adjacent sentences

Exception: Restate name at paragraph breaks

comedic_timing.description: Patterns for maximizing comedic impact through punchy, concise delivery - especially critical for romcom/ecchi comedy

patterns.english_pattern: Drop connecting words, use shorter sentence for punchline

examples.jp: こいつ、本が苦手というより頭を使うことが嫌いなんだよな
examples.literal: It's not that this girl hates books; she just hates using her brain.
examples.natural: She doesn't hate books. She hates thinking.

usage_rules: Split into two short sentences for comedic beat
Second sentence is the punchline - keep it shortest
Drop softening language like 'rather', 'it's just that'

patterns.japanese_structure: どこの世界に～するヤツがいるんだ
patterns.english_pattern: Drop rhetorical framing, state directly

examples.jp: どこの世界に人の部屋にやってきて、いきなり布団を敷き始めるヤツがいるんだ
examples.literal: Who in the world walks into someone's room and immediately starts laying out their futon?
examples.natural: Who just walks into someone's room and starts unrolling their futon?

usage_rules: Remove 'in the world' for punchier delivery
Drop modifiers like 'immediately' if they dilute impact
Keep verbs active and direct

patterns.english_pattern: Use blunt noun compounds, avoid flowery description

examples.jp: もう、オスになった駿太の匂いを楽しんでたのに
examples.literal: Aw, I was just enjoying the scent of Shunta-turned-man.
examples.natural: I was enjoying your man-smell.

usage_rules: Blunt compound nouns are funnier than descriptions
Drop possessive constructions when possible
Short = funnier for absurd situations

patterns.english_pattern: Reduce to colon format for deadpan delivery

examples.jp: おっぱいが見られないならこの旅館に用はない
examples.literal: Is it too heartless to think that if I can't see boobs, I have no business being at this inn?
examples.natural: Is it heartless to think: no boobs, no reason to be here?

usage_rules: Use colon to create comedic beat/pause
Reduce conditional to minimal phrase
Parallel structure amplifies humor (X, no Y)

patterns.english_pattern: State absurd situations in plain language

examples.jp: 幼なじみでも、高校生にもなったらお互いの家なんて行かないでしょ
examples.literal: Childhood friends or not, when you're in high school, you don't really go to each other's houses.
examples.natural: Childhood friends or not, high schoolers don't really go over to each other's houses, you know.

usage_rules: Avoid embellishing absurd situations
Direct statement > flowery description
Let situation be funny, not the language

patterns.english_pattern: Drop softening, use short exclamation for reaction

examples.jp: どうしてそこで田中が出て来るんだよっ！
examples.literal: Why does Tanaka have to come up now?!
examples.natural: Why does Tanaka have to come up now?!

usage_rules: Keep exclamations short and direct
Use repeated letters for emphasis (Tanakaaa!!)
Multiple exclamation marks for comedic intensity

patterns.english_pattern: Use 'There's no way' or direct negation

examples.jp: 俺が優里亜のこと臭いとか思うわけないだろ！
examples.literal: There's no way I'd ever think Yuria smells bad!
examples.natural: There's no way I'd ever think Yuria smells bad!

usage_rules: 'There's no way' for strong denial
Keep the absurd detail in the quote
Exclamation mark for emphasis

patterns.english_pattern: Keep repetition for comedic escalation

examples.jp: あーもう！　ち●ち●、ち●ち●うっさいし！
examples.literal: Ugh, enough! Penis, penis, you're so loud!
examples.natural: Ugh, enough! Penis, penis, you're so loud!

usage_rules: Preserve repetition of embarrassing/absurd words
Don't smooth out for elegance - repetition IS the joke
Works for escalating frustration/embarrassment

patterns.english_pattern: Direct comparison for absurd contrast

examples.jp: ほんとさ、うちの犬の方が利口なのおかしいでしょ
examples.literal: Honestly, it's ridiculous how much smarter my dog is than you.
examples.natural: Honestly, it's ridiculous how much smarter my dog is than you.

usage_rules: Keep absurd comparison direct
Don't soften the insult/comparison
Works for playful banter and teasing

usage_rules: Add question tags naturally: right?, yeah?, don't you think?
Can soften statements or seek agreement
Common in casual conversation for rapport building

patterns.english_pattern: Isn't it?, Right?, You know

examples.literal: That's bad, isn't it?
examples.natural: That's bad, isn't it?

usage_rules: じゃん is more casual/assertive than じゃない
Can express obviousness or shared knowledge
Often drops question mark for statements

patterns.english_pattern: I wonder, Maybe, I guess

examples.jp: 明日雨かな
examples.literal: I wonder if it will rain tomorrow
examples.natural: Wonder if it'll rain tomorrow.

usage_rules: Expresses uncertainty or tentative thinking
Can drop 'I wonder' for brevity in casual speech
Often used for self-directed questions

patterns.english_pattern: You see, That's because, The thing is

examples.jp: 忙しかったんだ
examples.literal: I was busy (explanatory)
examples.natural: I was busy, you see.

usage_rules: Adds explanatory/contextual nuance to statements
Often implies 'let me explain' or 'here's why'
Can be dropped in translation if context is clear

patterns.english_pattern: Probably, I bet, Must be

examples.jp: 彼は来るだろう
examples.literal: He will probably come
examples.natural: He'll probably come.

usage_rules: Expresses probability or assumption
Can seek confirmation (with rising intonation)
だろ is casual, でしょう is polite

patterns.english_pattern: I wonder if, Could it be

examples.jp: 本当なのか
examples.literal: I wonder if it's true
examples.natural: Is it really true?

usage_rules: Self-directed questioning or pondering
Often internal monologue in narrative
Can drop 'I wonder' in English for directness

patterns.english_pattern: Was it...?, Let me think, If I recall

examples.jp: 明日だっけ？
examples.literal: Was it tomorrow?
examples.natural: Was it tomorrow?

usage_rules: Indicates trying to recall information
Often translates with 'again' or 'was it'
Common in casual conversation

patterns.english_pattern: That's why, No wonder, Naturally

examples.jp: だから遅れたわけだ
examples.literal: That's why you were late
examples.natural: So that's why you were late.

usage_rules: Expresses logical conclusion or realization
Often shows understanding of cause-effect
Can be triumphant ('I knew it!') or neutral

emotional_nuance.description: Japanese modal particles and adverbs that add speaker attitude, uncertainty, or emotional coloring - essential for authentic character voice

negative_vectors.description: Suppress match when modifier is factual/quantitative rather than emotional/attitudinal
texts: exactly three, precisely measured, specifically at noon, quantitative amount
completely, totally, absolutely, entirely certain without emotional nuance
objective narration without speaker attitude, camera-eye description, pure action

patterns.english_pattern: Kind of, Somehow, Like, Sort of

examples.jp: なんか変な感じがする
examples.literal: I have a somehow strange feeling
examples.natural: Something feels off.

usage_rules: Expresses vague uncertainty or hesitation
Often untranslatable hedge - can drop entirely
Overuse creates Valley Girl speech - use sparingly

patterns.english_pattern: A bit, Kinda, A little, (or drop entirely)

examples.jp: ちょっと難しいかも
examples.literal: It might be a bit difficult
examples.natural: Might be kinda hard.

usage_rules: Softens statements to sound less direct
Common in requests: 'ちょっと待って' = 'wait a sec'
Can often be dropped in English without losing meaning

patterns.english_pattern: As expected, I knew it, Just as I thought, Sure enough

examples.jp: やっぱりそうだった
examples.literal: It was as expected
examples.natural: I knew it.

usage_rules: Confirms prior expectation or suspicion
やっぱり is casual, やはり is formal
Can express resignation, vindication, or confirmation

patterns.english_pattern: Even so, Even I, That's too much, As expected

examples.jp: さすがにそれは無理だ
examples.literal: Even so, that's impossible
examples.natural: Even I can't do that. / That's too much.

usage_rules: Expresses reaching a limit or exceeding expectations
Two meanings: (1) 'even I/you' (limit), (2) 'as expected'...
Context determines which meaning applies

patterns.english_pattern: No way, Surely not, Don't tell me, Could it be

examples.jp: まさか、そんなことないよね？
examples.literal: Surely not, that's not the case, right?
examples.natural: No way. That can't be true, right?

usage_rules: Expresses disbelief or strong doubt
Often rhetorical: speaker knows it's true but shocked
まさかね is dismissive: 'nah, can't be'

patterns.english_pattern: Could it be, By any chance, Maybe, Perhaps

examples.jp: もしかして怒ってる？
examples.literal: By any chance, are you angry?
examples.natural: Are you mad?

usage_rules: Expresses tentative hypothesis or realization
Often marks sudden understanding or suspicion
Can be excited discovery or worried question

patterns.english_pattern: Anyway, Might as well, It's not like, In the end

examples.jp: どうせ無理だし
examples.literal: Anyway it's impossible
examples.natural: It's hopeless anyway.

usage_rules: Expresses resignation or fatalism
Often dismissive or pessimistic tone
Can justify action: 'might as well since...'

patterns.english_pattern: Just in case, For now, Technically, I guess

examples.jp: 一応確認しておくね
examples.literal: I'll confirm just in case
examples.natural: I'll double-check just in case.

usage_rules: Hedges commitment or certainty
Multiple meanings: 'just in case', 'technically', 'for now'
Shows doing something without full confidence

patterns.english_pattern: For now, First, Anyway, Let's start with

examples.jp: とりあえずビール
examples.literal: For now, beer
examples.natural: Beer to start. / I'll have a beer.

rag_retrieval_strategy.description: How to retrieve patterns during translation

steps.name: Parse Japanese structure
steps.method: Identify particles, connectors, sentence patterns in source via grammar_pattern_detector (16 regex categories, 97 patterns)

steps.name: Batch embed & vector search
steps.method: Batch-embed all detected pattern contexts in 1 API call → ChromaDB cosine search filtered by category → return top-k matches

steps.name: Negative anchor filtering
steps.method: For each match, compute cosine similarity between query and category negative_vectors. If similarity > 0.72, apply proportional penalty (up to -0.15) to suppress false positives. Example: intensifiers pattern won't fire on 'completely certain' sentences.

steps.name: Threshold gate
steps.method: After penalty adjustment: similarity ≥ 0.78 → inject into prompt as few-shot example. 0.65-0.78 → log for audit. < 0.65 → discard.

steps.name: Priority ranking & injection
steps.method: Sort by CATEGORY_PRIORITIES (10=highest), then similarity. Inject top 3-5 high-confidence patterns as context for LLM.

steps.name: Post-process validation
steps.method: Check if LLM applied pattern correctly, suggest fixes if needed

negative_anchor_system.description: Prevents false-positive pattern matches by penalizing queries that are semantically close to known anti-patterns for each category

implementation.storage: negative_vectors.texts[] in each category — 3 English sentences describing what this category is NOT
implementation.embedding: Lazily batch-embedded on first get_bulk_guidance() call via Gemini Embedding 001, cached as numpy arrays
implementation.scoring: cosine_sim(query_embedding, negative_vector) → if > NEGATIVE_ANCHOR_THRESHOLD (0.72), penalty = overshoot × NEGATIVE_ANCHOR_PENALTY (0.15)
implementation.effect: A match with raw_similarity=0.82 but neg_penalty=0.08 becomes effective_similarity=0.74, dropping it from inject tier to log-only tier
